column2: MRS. PRIME READS HER RECANTATION.

column2: Above an hour had passed after the interruption mentioned at the end of the last chapter before Mrs. Ray and Rachel crossed back from the farm-house to the cottage, and when they went they went alone.
column3: Above an hour had passed after the interruption mentioned at the end of the last chapter before mrs Ray and Rachel crossed back from the farm house to the cottage, and when they went they went alone.

column2: During that hour they had been sitting in Mrs. Sturt's parlour; and when at last they got up to go they did not press Luke Rowan to go with them. Mrs. Prime was at the cottage, and it was necessary that everything should be explained to her before she was asked to give her hand to her future brother-in-law.
column3: During that hour they had been sitting in mrs Sturt's parlour; and when at last they got up to go they did not press luke Rowan to go with them. mrs Prime was at the cottage, and it was necessary that everything should be explained to her before she was asked to give her hand to her future brother in law.

column2: The farmer had come in and had joked his joke, and Mrs. Sturt had clacked over them as though they were a brood of chickens of her own hatching; and Mrs. Ray had smiled and cried, and sobbed and laughed till she had become almost hysterical. Then she had jumped up from her seat, saying, "Oh, dear, what will Dorothea think has become of us?"

column2: Rachel, as she followed her mother out from the farmyard gate, had not a word to say.

column3: The cup had been hardly given to her to drink before it had been again snatched away, and since then she had been left to think that the draught for which she longed would never again be offered to her lips.

column2: Mrs. Prime was still reading the serious book; but I am bound to say that her mind had not been wholly intent upon it during the long absence of her mother and sister.

column2: She had struggled for a time to ignore the slight fact that her companions were away gossiping with the neighbouring farmer's wife; she had made a hard fight with her book, pinning her eyes down upon the page over and over again, as though in pinning down her eyes she could pin down her mind also. But by degrees the delay became so long that she was tantalized into surmises as to the subject of their conversation.

column2: She had been loud and defiant in her denunciation when she had first suspected Rachel of having a lover. column2: When she had gone to Mrs. Tappitt's party, so consciously alive to the fact that he was to be there, she had told herself that she was sure she thought no more of him than of any other man that she might meet; but she now declared to herself that she had been a weak fool in thus attempting to deceive herself; that she had loved him from the first,--or at any rate from that evening when he had told her of the beauty of the clouds; and that from that day to the present hour there had been no other chance of happiness to her but that chance which had now been so wondrously decided in her favour.

column3: mrs Prime did make some effort at conversation; she did endeavour to receive the young man as her future brother in law; she was gracious to him with such graciousness as she possessed;--but the duration of their meal was terribly long, and even mrs Ray herself felt relieved when the two lovers went forth together for their evening walk.

column2: I think there must have been some triumph in Rachel's heart as she tied on her hat before she started. I think she must have remembered the evening on which her sister had been so urgent with her to go to the Dorcas meeting;--when she had so obstinately refused that invitation, and had instead gone out to meet the Tappitt girls, and had met with them the young man of whom her sister had before been speaking with so much horror.
column3: I think there must have been some triumph in Rachel's heart as she tied on her hat before she started. I think she must have remembered the evening on which her sister had been so urgent with her to go to the Dorcas meeting;--when she had so obstinately refused that invitation, and had instead gone out to meet the Tappitt girls, and had met with them the young man of whom her sister had before been speaking with so much horror.

column2: Now he was there on purpose to take her with him, and she went forth with him, leaning lovingly on his arm, while yet close under her sister's eyes.
column3: Now he was there on purpose to take her with him, and she went forth with him, leaning lovingly on his arm, while yet close under her sister's eyes.

column2: I think there must have been a gleam of triumph in her face as she put her hand with such confidence well round her lover's arm.
column3: I think there must have been a gleam of triumph in her face as she put her hand with such confidence well round her lover's arm.

column2: Girls do triumph in their lovers,--in their acknowledged and permitted lovers, as young men triumph in their loves which are not acknowledged or perhaps permitted.
column3: Girls do triumph in their lovers,--in their acknowledged and permitted lovers, as young men triumph in their loves which are not acknowledged or perhaps permitted.

column2: A man's triumph is for the most part over when he is once allowed to take his place at the family table, as a right, next to his betrothed.
column3: A man's triumph is for the most part over when he is once allowed to take his place at the family table, as a right, next to his betrothed.

column2: He begins to feel himself to be a sacrificial victim,--done up very prettily with blue and white ribbons round his horns, but still an ox prepared for sacrifice.
column3: He begins to feel himself to be a sacrificial victim,--done up very prettily with blue and white ribbons round his horns, but still an ox prepared for sacrifice.

column2: But the girl feels herself to be exalted for those few weeks as a conqueror, and to be carried along in an ovation of which that bucolic victim, tied round with blue ribbons on to his horns, is the chief grace and ornament.
column3: But the girl feels herself to be exalted for those few weeks as a conqueror, and to be carried along in an ovation of which that bucolic victim, tied round with blue ribbons on to his horns, is the chief grace and ornament.

column2: In this mood, no doubt, both Rachel and Luke Rowan went forth, leaving the two widows together in the cottage.
column3: In this mood, no doubt, both Rachel and luke Rowan went forth, leaving the two widows together in the cottage.

column2: It is pretty to see her so happy, isn't it now? said Mrs. Ray.
column3: It is pretty to see her so happy, isn't it now? said mrs Ray.

column2: The question for the moment made Mrs. Prime uncomfortable and almost wretched, but it gave her the opportunity which in her heart she desired of recanting her error in regard to Luke Rowan's character. She wished to give in her adhesion to the marriage,--to be known to have acknowledged its fitness so that she could, with some true word of sisterly love, wish her sister well.
column3: The question for the moment made mrs Prime uncomfortable and almost wretched, but it gave her the opportunity which in her heart she desired of recanting her error in regard to luke Rowan's character. She wished to give in her adhesion to the marriage,--to be known to have acknowledged its fitness so that she could, with some true word of sisterly love, wish her sister well.

column2: In Rachel's presence she could not have first made this recantation.
column3: In Rachel's presence she could not have first made this recantation.

column2: Though Rachel spoke no triumph, there was a triumph in her eye, which prevented almost the possibility of such yielding on the part of Dorothea.
column3: Though Rachel spoke no triumph, there was a triumph in her eye, which prevented almost the possibility of such yielding on the part of Dorothea.

column2: But when the thing should have been once done, when she should once have owned that Rachel was not wrong, then gradually she could bring herself round to the utterance of some kindly expression.
column3: But when the thing should have been once done, when she should once have owned that Rachel was not wrong, then gradually she could bring herself round to the utterance of some kindly expression.

column2: Pretty, she said; "yes, it is pretty.
column3: Pretty, she said; "yes, it is pretty.

column2: I do not know that anybody ever doubted its prettiness."
column3: I do not know that anybody ever doubted its prettiness."

column2: And isn't it nice too?	And isn't it nice too?
column3: true

column2: Dear girl!
column3: Dear girl!

column2: It does make me so happy to see her light-hearted again.
column3: It does make me so happy to see her light-hearted again.

column2: She has had a sad time of it, Dorothea, since we made her write that letter to him; a very sad time of it."
column3: She has had a sad time of it, Dorothea, since we made her write that letter to him; a very sad time of it."

column2: People here, mother, do mostly have what you call a sad time of it. Are we not taught that it is better for us that it should be so?	People here, mother, do mostly have what you call a sad time of it. Are we not taught that it is better for us that it should be so?
column3: false

column2: Have not you and I, mother, had a sad time of it?
column3: Have not you and I, mother, had a sad time of it?

column2: It would be all sad enough if this were to be the end of it."
column3: It would be all sad enough if this were to be the end of it."

column2: Yes, just so; of course we know that.	Yes, just so; of course we know that.
column3: true

column2: But it can't be wrong that she should be happy now, when things are so bright all around her.
column3: But it can't be wrong that she should be happy now, when things are so bright all around her.

column2: You wouldn't have thought it better for her, or for him either, that they should be kept apart, seeing that they really love each other?"
column3: You wouldn't have thought it better for her, or for him either, that they should be kept apart, seeing that they really love each other?"

column2: No; I don't say that.	No; I don't say that.
column3: true

column2: If they love one another of course it is right that they should marry.
column3: If they love one another of course it is right that they should marry.

column2: I only wish we had known him longer."
column3: I only wish we had known him longer."

column2: I am not sure that these things always go much better because young people have known each other all their lives.	I am not sure that these things always go much better because young people have known each other all their lives.
column3: false

column2: It seems to be certain that he is an industrious, steady young man.
column3: It seems to be certain that he is an industrious, steady young man.

column2: Everybody seems to speak well of him now."
column3: Everybody seems to speak well of him now."

column2: Well, mother, I have nothing to say against him,--not a word.	Well, mother, I have nothing to say against him,--not a word.
column3: true

column2: And if it will give Rachel any pleasure,--though I don't suppose it will, the least in the world; but if it would, she may know that I think she has done wisely to accept him."
column3: And if it will give Rachel any pleasure,--though I don't suppose it will, the least in the world; but if it would, she may know that I think she has done wisely to accept him."

column2: Indeed it will; the greatest pleasure.
column3: Indeed it will; the greatest pleasure.

column2: And I hope they will be happy together for very many years.	And I hope they will be happy together for very many years.
column3: true

column2: I love Rachel dearly, though I fear she does not think so, and anything I have said, I have said in love, not in anger."
column3: I love Rachel dearly, though I fear she does not think so, and anything I have said, I have said in love, not in anger."

column2: I'm sure of that, Dorothea.
column3: I'm sure of that, Dorothea.

column2: Now that she is to be settled in life as a married woman, of course she must not look for counsel either to you or to me.	Now that she is to be settled in life as a married woman, of course she must not look for counsel either to you or to me.
column3: false

column2: She must obey him, and I hope that God may give him grace to direct her steps aright."
column3: She must obey him, and I hope that God may give him grace to direct her steps aright."

column2: Amen! said Mrs. Ray, solemnly.
column3: Amen! said mrs Ray, solemnly.

column2: It was thus that Mrs. Prime read her recantation, which was repeated on that evening to Rachel with some little softening touches.
column3: It was thus that mrs Prime read her recantation, which was repeated on that evening to Rachel with some little softening touches.

column2: You won't be living together in the same house after a bit, said Mrs. Ray, thinking, with some sadness, that those little evening festivities of buttered toast and thick cream were over for her now,--"but I do hope you will be friends."
column3: You won't be living together in the same house after a bit, said mrs Ray, thinking, with some sadness, that those little evening festivities of buttered toast and thick cream were over for her now,--"but I do hope you will be friends."

column2: Of course we will, mamma.	Of course we will, mamma.
column3: true

column2: She has only to put out her hand the least little bit in the world, and I will go the rest of the way.
column3: She has only to put out her hand the least little bit in the world, and I will go the rest of the way.

column2: As for her living, I don't know what will be best about that, because Luke says that of course you'll come and live with us."
column3: As for her living, I don't know what will be best about that, because luke says that of course you'll come and live with us."

column2: It was two or three days after this that Rachel saw the Tappitt girls for the first time since the fact of her engagement had become known. It was in the evening, and she had been again walking with Luke, when she met them; but at that moment she was alone.
column3: It was two or three days after this that Rachel saw the Tappitt girls for the first time since the fact of her engagement had become known. It was in the evening, and she had been again walking with luke, when she met them; but at that moment she was alone.

column2: Augusta would have turned boldly away, though they had all come closely together before either had been aware of the presence of the other.
column3: Augusta would have turned boldly away, though they had all come closely together before either had been aware of the presence of the other.

column2: But to this both Martha and Cherry objected.
column3: But to this both Martha and Cherry objected.

column2: We have heard of your engagement, said Martha, "and we congratulate you.
column3: We have heard of your engagement, said Martha, "and we congratulate you.

column2: You have heard, of course, that we are going to move to Torquay, and we hope that you will be comfortable at the brewery."
column3: You have heard, of course, that we are going to move to Torquay, and we hope that you will be comfortable at the brewery."

column2: Yes, said Augusta, "the place isn't what it used to be, and so we think it best to go.
column3: Yes, said Augusta, "the place isn't what it used to be, and so we think it best to go.

column2: Mamma has already looked at a villa near Torquay, which will suit us delightfully."
column3: Mamma has already looked at a villa near Torquay, which will suit us delightfully."

column2: Then they passed on, but Cherry remained behind to say another word. "I am so happy," said Cherry, "that you and he have hit it off.
column3: Then they passed on, but Cherry remained behind to say another word. "I am so happy," said Cherry, "that you and he have hit it off.

column2: He's a charming fellow, and I always said he was to fall in love with you. After the ball of course there wasn't a doubt about it.
column3: He's a charming fellow, and I always said he was to fall in love with you. After the ball of course there wasn't a doubt about it.

column2: Mind you send us cake, dear; and by-and-by we'll come and see you at the old place, and be better friends than ever we were."
column3: Mind you send us cake, dear; and by and by we'll come and see you at the old place, and be better friends than ever we were."
